12148: Treachery.author: Gwafa_Hazid
12148: Treachery.text_parsed: Really, you don't get the flavor? For most of the "Control Magics", you, the caster, must magically dominate the creature being subdued. But Treachery on the other hand is the individual coming to you of their own free will, adding his own resources to your own; thus, the untapping of your lands. All you need to do, flavor-wise, is to entice the prospective betrayer with promises of greatness and wealth, without actually contributing anything. If anything, having to tap the lands in the first place is there merely for balance purposes, rather than flavor. Just a little aside: if we're going with this interpretation of the flavor for this particular card, what'd be best to do is to make it another Pact. Get the guy on your side, repay the promises made after he's joined you; i.e., your next turn.

12148: Treachery.author: ratchet1215
12148: Treachery.text_parsed:
This card is broken. Seriously, getting a Mind Control FOR FREE by turn five is just way, way too powerful. There aren't many cards that cause me to complain when they're cast against me, but I don't feel guilty at all doing so with this one since MaRo himself says these cards should never have been printed.

The "free spells" mechanic was fundamentally flawed to begin with; it's just impossible to scale the costs of these things properly. Maybe it could've worked, but not with the way Magic's mana system works; this was an interesting design area to explore that went down in a giant Fireball.
12148: Treachery.text_posted:
This card is broken.  Seriously, getting a [autocard]Mind Control[/autocard] FOR FREE by turn five is just way, way too powerful.  There aren't many cards that cause me to complain when they're cast against me, but I don't feel guilty at all doing so with this one since MaRo himself says these cards should never have been printed.

The "free spells" mechanic was fundamentally flawed to begin with; it's just impossible to scale the costs of these things properly.  Maybe it could've worked, but not with the way Magic's mana system works; this was an interesting design area to explore that went down in a giant [autocard]Fireball[/autocard].

12148: Treachery.author: Maroon_Lotus
12148: Treachery.text_parsed:
"I got a great idea. We should take Control Magic, make it cost {1} more, but then make it cost 0. Yea, that makes sense."

Not joking though, this card and Time Spiral take 2 already broken mechanics, slap an even more broken mechanic on top of them (the untap mechanic) and the two mechanics just happen to complement each other extremely well, especially in the case of Time Spiral. They should print some more "free" mana cost cards, except ones that don't already have a broken mechanic on top of them, and maybe instead of untapping lands just say add the casting cost back into your mana pool.

13087: Masticore.author: Lord_Ascapelion
13087: Masticore.text_parsed:
I don't think this would be played much, if reprinted today. Yes, it's efficient as heck, but cards need a proper environment to thrive in- just look at Phyrexian Obliterator. From what I understand, this guy gave Draw-Go type of decks a strong creature (Morphling helped, as well.) These days, Draw-Go doesn't really exist anymore and the card disadvantage would probably leave a bad taste in people's mouths. Cards can't really be judged in a vacuum- environment is everything. A card could be absolutely fantastic, but if it doesn't have the proper support, it's just an orphan.

That said, I still think Masticore is awesome. I would probably play him in a deck that took advantage of the discard- Madness or Reanimator.

13087: Masticore.author: JimmyNoobPlayer
13087: Masticore.text_parsed:
@Kikke:
I just watched someone open a pack of Unlimited Edition on a Youtube video. Alongside cards like Mox Ruby and Sinkhole, the pack included Ironroot Treefolk and Gray Ogre. Creatures back then sucked. I know creatures in Urza's Saga were much better than in Unlimited, but they were still far from overpowering non-creature spells like Dark Ritual and Yawgmoth's Will.

The game is designed to include creature combat. Combat is extremely flavorful and fun, includes very difficult skill-testing decisions, and is filled with opportunities to show off discovered synergies. Not having decent creatures shuts off an important part of the game. In fact, I think it's reasonable to say it's the most important part of the game. The designers and developers today are careful to make both creatures and non-creature spells powerful enough to use.

And now for something completely different... You can include an empty tag in the middle of a word to bypass the censoring. It'll look like this, but with square brackets instead of parentheses: (autocard multiverseid="249365")Deep An(i)(/i)alysis(/autocard). You also have to use the multiverse id instead of the default autocarding because Gatherer wont recognize the word.

Deep Analysis
Rootwater Thief
script

Ooh, that last one made me feel dirty. :-)

13821: Landslide.author: The_Murderauder
13821: Landslide.text_parsed:
@retrovirus61: While it's true that it does have that potential, it's not actually likely that that would happen. The odds of getting a 4x4 (4 lands on turn 4) in a deck that plays 20 or fewer (most RDW builds) is pretty low, much less a 5x5. And if you get a 5x5 in a burn deck like that, then it's probably not working how it was supposed to.

Also, as aznxknightz mentioned, it was competing for a spot with Fireblast, which was the better card by a large margin.

I think this is being overlooked as a decent finisher for a RUW control build, where you're likely to get up to 7+ lands anyway (many of them duals with the mountain subtype), and you generally have trouble dealing large chunks of damage on the cheap. Make sure to float some mana for counterspells, though!

13821: Landslide.author: LordRandomness
13821: Landslide.text_parsed: Fireblast is two mountains for four damage, this is X mountains plus one red for X damage. It's similar to the Lightning Bolt/Blaze comparison in that one trades raw power at one level for versatility at all levels, but the sorts of decks that use these effects tend not to get above four land that often anyway.

14442: Apprentice Necromancer.author: joboo99
14442: Apprentice Necromancer.text_parsed:
i use this in a dragon reanimator deck and it works great.

here is the combo.

second turn play apprentice necromancer
third turn play buried alive
4th turn sac the necromancer bring out bladewing, then tyrant of jund and attack with both.
end of turn sac bladewing, tyrant of jund stays in play and from now on all dragons you controll gain haste

you should be able to end a game within 6 turns at most.

But you're right nibelheim_valesti, this would at least give this combo some sense...then again, it can neither be argued that it's a block-constructed combo, nor that it's a cheap monocolored one anymore, so in the end we're just left with a pretty crappy Legacy combo^^

14442: Apprentice Necromancer.author: SubstantiaNigra
14442: Apprentice Necromancer.text_parsed:
Turn 1: Swamp, Dark Ritual, Apprentice Necromancer, Entomb Protean Hulk.

Turn 2: Swamp, sacrifice Apprentice Necromancer, return Protean Hulk to the battlefield, hit for 6, sacrifice it at end of turn, search for 4x Gravecrawler and 1x Apprentice Necromancer and put onto the battlefield.

Turn 3: Swamp...

And if you're lucky enough to have/draw another Entomb, you could Entomb Anger and repeat this process multiple times within that turn, pulling out your 4x Carnophage, 4x Putrid Imp, any of your 3 CMC zombie lords (e.g. Cemetery Reaper, Death Baron, Lord of the Undead, etc.), your Gravedigger (thus getting back your Apprentice Necromancer instantly) or your Grave Titan.

15127: Flicker.author: iondragonx
15127: Flicker.text_parsed:
Underrated utility card.
Other than saving your own creatures from death; you can use it to harm creatures that depend on +1/+1 counters like Protean Hydra. Any permanent that depends on counters to use, like Planeswalkers or Vivid lands, are rendered useless. You can disenchant Auras on opposing creatures. You can unequip opposing creatures. You can really mess with opposing cards that require sacrifices when they are brought into play, like Orzhov Basilica or other Ravnica lands.

15127: Flicker.author: Ideatog
15127: Flicker.text_parsed:
'Sup Blazer_Dawg?

Yes, you can indeed use a planeswalker's ability, then flicker it and use its ability again that same turn. Once it leaves play, it stops being the same 'casting' of the card, same as if it had gone to the graveyard or been permanently exiled somehow. It triggers leaves play and comes into play effects- so its loyalty counters will reset too.

Now if you found a way to phase it out...

15127: Flicker.author: whiteshadw
15127: Flicker.text_parsed:
@iondragonx

This effect doesn't always remove counters, it just resets a permanent to the state it would have been in if it was just put into play. So this card can only really help vivid lands, as when they come back they get all their counters back. It also situationally both helps and hurts planeswalkers. I think the best thing to do to a planeswalker with this would be to use a powerful minus ability, use this on the walker to refresh its loyalty counters and then use another walker ability as it will be a fresh version of the walker. You could also do what you may have been sugesting and use this on an opponents walker who is about to go ultimate, resetting them to fresh.

But you are right, this does wreck Protean Hydra, since zero mana was spent on x for the new version it will come into play with zero counters and die as a state based action when it is 0/0.

15127: Flicker.author: Fadingstar
15127: Flicker.text_parsed:
You should NOT be using this card to target creatures. There are many other cards that do a better job than this (Cloudshift, Momentary Blink, or Otherworldly Journey) The big downside is that it does it at sorcery speed, but the upside is that it targets all types of permanents. So instead:

Reset your imprint artifacts: Prototype Portal, Isochron Scepter, Soul Foundry

Reset your enchantments to new relevant targets: Oblivion RIng, Nevermore, Runed Halo, Detention Sphere

Reset Planeswalker counters, then use their ability twice in one turn: ALL OF THEM

Furthermore, you can reset cumulative upkeep counters and fading counters which appear on enchantments, artifacts, and lands.

Though I suppose you could always blow stuff up with Spine of Ish Sah or Reality Acid.
15127: Flicker.text_posted:
You should [u]NOT[/u] be using this card to target creatures.  There are many other cards that do a better job than this ([autocard]Cloudshift[/autocard], [autocard]Momentary Blink[/autocard], or [autocard]Otherworldly Journey[/autocard])  The big downside is that it does it at sorcery speed, but the upside is that it targets all types of permanents.  So instead:

15138: Academy Rector.author: DarthParallax
15138: Academy Rector.text_parsed:
OMNISCIENCE! FIRST!
GRISELBRAND!
FREAKING GAME

1x Puresteel Paladin
?x giant pile of Mirrodin "Sword of"- at least 10, maybe full 20
4x Academy Rector
1x Omniscience
1x Necropotence
?x giant pile of Eldrazi, Praetors, Legendary Dragons, Legendary Angels, Progenitus, or
Mythic Phyrexian Artifact Beasts, or whatever stupid crap you have lying around.

*x minimum amount of lands/artifact mana sources necessary to cast Academy Rector, Entomb/Reanimate (for Gris) plus some way to kill Rector as fast as possible. (a 200-400 card deck is completely reasonable depending how many Legendary Creatures you feel like tossing in)

Step 1: You Reanimate Griselbrand
Step 2: You cheat Omniscience into play
Step 3: You drop an assload of creatures onto the battlefield, including 1 Puresteel Paladin and
a massive cache of equipment.
Step 4: You destroy everyone because somewhere in that pile of awesome, something is going to be giving everything haste...and probably a lot more! xD

With, like, Sol Rings and junk, you might be able to do it turn 2 or 3.

EDIT: Actually NoIHaven't, thanks to Enter the Infinite, I like my 400-card Massive Stupid Deck.Deck Idea Better ^_^

In VINTAGE, no less, we have: Tutors and Jank and Cripe.

So. What we want to make, is, let's say my first numbers were too big...how about a 150-card deck?

We start with the Obvious Offenders, Restricted stuff like Necropotence and Power & Co.

With enough Tutors, and the best Mana Ramp in the Game, we go and get Enter The Infinite, and we Academy Rector for Omniscience. We SHIT our one-hundred-and-fifty-card deck onto the table, by no less than Turn 4. We accept that Vintage is usually a faster kill. We accept that not winning most of our games is worth being able to win the games we do win by the most massive possible overkill imaginable. (Remember- Mirror Gallery is a thing. 4 Emrakul's should be ONLY THE BEGINNING. You ought to get away with 4 Oracle of Mul Daya so you can play those 4 Dark Depths and get those 4 Marit Lage tokens too with your 4 Vampire Hexmages.

Enter the Omnipotence.Dec


I'm sorry, but if I wanted a 'Streamlined for Competitive Storm' deck NoIHaven't, I wouldn't be autocarding to Omniscience or Enter the Infinite because you don't strictly need them. :P

15138: Academy Rector.author: Gameguy602
15138: Academy Rector.text_parsed:
Use in a Zedruu the Greathearted EDH to cheat Omniscience into play, in order to Enter the Infinite, tap into the Leyline of Anticipation, and take refuge in your Island Sanctuary. Then put Graceful Adept and Tamiyo, the Moon Sage into play and work your way to Tamiyo's emblem, countering any attempts to remove either of them. After you have it, pull all your stuff from eternity, drop a Paradigm Shift and Ponder for a bit.

You are now a god, free to Donate and Brand as you see fit. And there are so many ways to give other people's stuff away too (give them the enchantment not the target, just Disenchant when you want to take something else). If anyone tries to pull anything you don't want them to, you can Trickbind or Cancel it.

At this point, you can crush everyone anytime you want with infinite Sudden Shocks, or you could make things interesting and shift cards around until there's one opponent left and then flip a coin to decide if you'll concede (or maybe just toss a Sway of the Stars and duke it out).

15142: Opalescence.author: PjotrV
15142: Opalescence.text_parsed:
After turning into a creature, does an enchantment's sub type (eg. Honden of Cleansing Fire's is 'Shrine') count as a creature type?

Probably not. Dryad Arbor's 'forest' subtype isn't a creature type either (likewise its 'dryad' subtype isn't a land type.)
Also consider the tribal spells (e.g. Tarfire); 'goblin' isn't an instant subtype just because it appears on an instant.

Also, Opalescensce doesn't remove the enchantment type.

15142: Opalescence.author: Lord_of_Tresserhorn
15142: Opalescence.text_parsed:
Hmmm... The Doubling Season + Followed Footsteps combo creates an interesting mathematical construct. I'm not sure if you can analytically describe it.

The key is a semi-exponential 2^X + X function.

You begin with 1 Doubling Season.

Next turn, you get two more, so in total 1 +2^1 = 1 + 2 = 3.

Then 3 + 2^3 = 11, and then the big jump, 11 + 2^11 = 11 + 2048 = 2059.

The next step is still doable on your calculator of your computer, it gives you 2059 + 6.6 x 10^619 (!!!!!) 5/5 creatures. That's not just a bit over a Googol (10^100), it's 10^519 times larger.

The next step is probably impossible to compute.

15142: Opalescence.author: The_Trendkill
15142: Opalescence.text_parsed:
A detailed overview the Doubling Season + Followed Footsteps interaction:

You start with your Opalescence-animated Doubling Season enchanted with Followed Footsteps. Followed Footsteps will trigger at the beginning of your next upkeep and will attempt to put a token copy of Doubling Season onto the battlefield. Your original Doubling Season's replacement effect will modify this and you will instead end up getting two token copies of Doubling Season.

On your next upkeep, the replacement effects from your multiple copies of Doubling Season start chaining together, and the crazy exponential growth begins. This time, Followed Footsteps will trigger and your three copies of Doubling Season will each act on the trigger, each one doubling the previous amount. The first trigger will result in two copies, the second four, and the third eight; 2 ^ 3 = 8. You will put eight token copies of Doubling Season onto the battlefield.

Now, there's an easily followed pattern. Each of your upkeeps you will put 2 ^ X token copies of Doubling Season onto the battlefield, where X is the number of Doubling Seasons you control. This results in you having X + (2 ^ X) Doubling Seasons. The trouble with this is that the numbers quickly get impossibly huge after this point. Just to demonstrate...

T1: 1 Doubling Season
T2: 3 Doubling Seasons
T3: 11 Doubling Seasons
T4: 2059 Doubling Seasons
T5: 6.619 x 10 ^ 619 Doubling Seasons (620 decimal digits long, MUCH larger than a googol)
T6: 10 ^ 10 ^ 10 ^ 2.79 Doubling Seasons (larger than a googolplex)
T7: 10 ^ 10 ^ 10 ^ 10 ^ 2.79 Doubling Seasons
T8: 10 ^ 10 ^ 10 ^ 10 ^ 10 ^ 2.79 Doubling Seasons

... and so on. The pattern in steps 6, 7, and 8 likely continues, but Mathematica got mad at me and wont tell me any more answers.

15142: Opalescence.author: Aquillion
15142: Opalescence.text_parsed:
Combo: Play Humility and Opalescence. After your opponent tries to parse the errata and has their brain explode, you win by default. Whatever you do, though, be careful not to read the errata or start to think about how the cards interact yourself!

I propose an alternative errata: "If a player deliberately causes Humility and Opalescence to be in play simultaneously, their opponent may punch them in the face."

More serious combo: Opalescence + Enchanted Evening turns all permanents into creatures with P/T equal to their casting cost... and then destroys all lands, because they're 0/0. And continues to destroy any new lands that enter play, forever. 0cc artifact mana dies, too. For extra fun, combine with Parapet or Layline of Vitality so you can save your lands.

15142: Opalescence.author: SevesDariku
15142: Opalescence.text_parsed:
This has some really amusing interactions with the Theros enchantment creatures. Near as I can figure, if you play this down AFTER a god, devotion basically becomes meaningless, as all the gods are made into creatures ANYWAY, but their P/T gets nerfed.

If you play this BEFORE a god comes into play, they seem to still require devotion, but will have their P/T nerfed to their casting cost as well.

As far as other enchantment creatures go, P/T gets replaced by CMC/CMC, which is nice for any of them that spend mana on fancy keywords. Still does not affect bestowed creatures, as Opalescence does not apply to auras.

15143: Replenish.author: scumbling1
15143: Replenish.text_parsed:
"How does this card affect Erayo Essence?"

There are four characteristics of permanents: tapped / untapped, phased in / phased out, face up / face down, and flipped / unflipped. Unless something says otherwise, a permanent entering any zone begins untapped, phased in, face up, and unflipped. Whenever your Erayo's Essence changes zones from the battlefield to the graveyard, it ends up there unflipped and as a consequence is a creature card. Replenish will not return Erayo to play.

15143: Replenish.author: DarthParallax
15143: Replenish.text_parsed:
You know, this kind of tutor+ effect, especially when it gets its fingers into the graveyard, is pretty much always undercosted and makes broken cards, not so much because RnD are trying to destroy Magic with combo decks, but because you are setting to make a card that has an inherently uncostable effect: you want to do something that really shouldn't even be getting done in the first place. That's what designing cards for Johnny often entails. :p


However, this card I think is actually fine as is and I'd enjoy seeing a reprint. Sometimes, not always, but sometimes, the enablers are not really to blame and the targets really are just too dumb-good. In this case, it's the 2nd-degree enablers- the ones that let you land whatever stuff into your graveyard you want, that are to me the more dangerous cards, in the long scheme of things, than Replenish itself.

15154: Rescue.text_parsed:
It's indeed very hand for Stasis decks, but unfortunately i can't think of much more.
Of course it's cheaper than any other bounces if you want to trigger cip/etb effects, but Vedalken Mastermind is most often the better Choice for such decks - and will also do an accordant job in Stasis decks.

I'd play such a card as cantrip or slowtrip only, though. The card disadvantage normally isn't worth it.

On top of this, Chain of Vapor will most often do this card's job just as well while being much more versatile by itself.

15161: Private Research.author: Aquillion
15161: Private Research.text_parsed:
Note that you can place this card on an opponent's creature, then kill it yourself. That is, in fact, generally a better option -- if you place it on your creature, your opponent is going to (if possible) kill it quickly to prevent you from getting too many cards (possibly even a two-for-one).

But if you put it on their creature, it puts them in a quandary -- they can't kill it themselves without at least breaking even with you and probably giving you a two-for-one (because they'll likely have to waste a card killing it.) Plus it's only one mana, so forcing them to kill their creature even by chump-blocking with it is not bad. More likely they'll be forced to wait a while, at which point you can kill the creature with removal and get a bunch of cards.
15161: Private Research.text_posted:
Note that you can place this card on an opponent's creature, then kill it yourself.  That is, in fact, generally a better option -- if you place it on your creature, your opponent is going to (if possible) kill it quickly to prevent you from getting too many cards (possibly even a two-for-one).

But if you put it on [i]their[/i] creature, it puts them in a quandary -- they can't kill it themselves without at least breaking even with you and probably giving you a two-for-one (because they'll likely have to waste a card killing it.)  Plus it's only one mana, so forcing them to kill their creature even by chump-blocking with it is not bad.  More likely they'll be forced to wait a while, at which point you can kill the creature with removal and get a bunch of cards.

15163: Iridescent Drake.author: Mode
15163: Iridescent Drake.text_parsed:
Looks like that card kind of inspired Evershrike, although with much more blue flavor - it takes control of an aura when casting the creature instead of reanimating the creature by casting an aura (like Animate Dead).

Using Auras with it that have a trigger when they enter of leave the battlefield should proof to be the most useful with it.
False Demise or Shade's Form for example create a great loop!
Unless your opponent exiles your Drake it will always return - now if you need a win-con just use a saccing engine.
Pattern of Rebirth also does a good job, and Bequeathal can provide some cheap card advantage.

There are also other notable cards, such as Private Research, Elephant Guide, Griffin Guide or Necromancer's Magemark, although these are by far not as awesome as the other alternatives.

15168: Donate.author: DrJack
15168: Donate.text_parsed:
"This is an example of a well-designed card."

BZZZZZZZZZZZT. Wrong. Do not pass "Go", do not collect $200.
Donate + Delusions of Grandeur* = nearly guaranteed victory for yourself, and a fairly easy 2 card combo to pull off. Play the Delusions, pay the cumulative upkeep a couple of turns, then donate. You'll keep your 20 life you gained, and when your opponent can't pay the upkeep (which will be very soon now, being that it will probably be a 6-mana upkeep cost by then), he'll lose 20 life - unpreventable loss of life. How do you recover from that?

Yes, this was the original ridiculous broken 2-card combo before Painter's Servant and Grindstone. Guys, there was always a reason it was never too easy to "donate" one of your cards to your opponent just like that. But the "Wizards" seem to always leap before they look when it comes to breaking sacred rules of this game.

Before this, the nastiest 2-card combo was Lich plus Mirror Universe, which was considerably harder to pull off and carried much more risk, and also a bit easier to recover from (a simple Healing Salve would save the opponent, and you'd still be in danger from your Lich).

* OK, I realize the actual name was "Illusions of Grandeur", but I hate the Wizards of the Coast's tendancy for a poor grasp of the English language.

Before this, the nastiest 2-card combo was [autocard]Lich[/autocard] plus [autocard]Mirror Universe[/autocard], which was considerably harder to pull off and carried much more risk, and also a bit easier to recover from (a simple [autocard]Healing Salve[/autocard] would save the opponent, and you'd still be in danger from your Lich).

* OK, I realize the actual name was "[autocard]Illusions of Grandeur[/autocard]", but I hate the Wizards of the Coast's tendancy for a poor grasp of the English language.

Whoops, for 10 years you've all been doing it wrong. That Illusions of Grandeur deck? Yeah apparently Donate was extremely broken BEFORE that card was made, with two OTHER cards that I am fairly certain no healthy mind could possibly think of Donating...>.>

Thankfully, JacktheStripper doesn't have a healthy mind, so when I looked up Oath of Lim-Dûl I saw him say this:

"Donate this and Necropotence. Hurts like hell unless I'm reading a rule wrong."


......


......

That's right folks. Somewhere, someone out there is busy breaking Necropotence BY DONATING IT?!?!

And it works. My God there is something wrong with that person's brain. And something even more wrong than I thought with Necropotence. InQuest gave it a 0/5 before later changing to 5/5. It's possible that when Ice Age wasn't so old and Urza's Saga was brand new, this combo would have torn up people just as well as the 'conventional' uses of Necropotence that were discovered (But were very much unconventional ways to play MAGIC. Back then anyway.)

15180: Plague Dogs.author: Hepatizon
15180: Plague Dogs.text_parsed:
I do so miss this art style. This, to me, is exactly as a Phyrexian should look (with, obviously, an appropriate nod from Mortis Dogs) comparable in my mind to the original Phyrexian Hulk, Order of Yawgmoth and Phyrexian Colossus art.

Gameplay-wise, it is still decent. I'm admittedly one of those players that begins to wring his hands at CMC of 5 (without it having quite the bang for the buck that I'd ressurrect) but it at least seems to have some decent bang for its buck, having both the incentive not to kill it and the potential to sacrifice it. All-in-all, I rather like it.

15183: Dying Wail.author: lukemol
15183: Dying Wail.text_parsed:
If you have to play this, play it right before killing the creature. It can be used well if you have removal. To that end, it has potential to be better than Mind Rot simply for being cheaper. Ideally you combo this with a Lightning Bolt on a creature with toughness 3 or less, or play it during your second main phase when a larger creature's already taken damage and Lightning Bolt to finish it off. Or you could play it on your own creature right before sacrificing it to some other ability.

It has potential, but it's not always useful.

15189: Body Snatcher.author: Paolino
15189: Body Snatcher.text_parsed:
Turn 1
- Swamp -> ;
- Carrion Feeder.
Turn 2
- Second Swamp -> ;
- With cast Dark Ritual -> ;
- With cast Body Snatcher and discard Emrakul;
- Emrakul's triggered ability (shuffle your graveyard into your library) goes on the stack;
- Sacrifice Body Snatcher to Carrion Feeder in response to the triggered ability;
- Body Snatcher's triggered ability goes on the stack above Emrakul's;
- Carrion Feeder's activated ability goes on the top of the stack;
- Carrion Feeder's ability resolves and it gets its +1/+1 counter;
- Body Snatcher's triggered ability resolves and Emrakul enters;
- Emrakul's triggered ability resolves and you shuffle your graveyard into your library;
- ENJOY YOUR SECOND TURN ANNIHILATOR 15/15!!!

15189: Body Snatcher.author: Sharu
15189: Body Snatcher.text_parsed:
I firmly believe this is an excellent card.
Its power and toughness are virtually irrelevant, as you want it to die.
A beautiful peace of reanimation, if you can call it that. It's closer to cheating it to play, effect wise. Assuming you target the card you discarded, of course.

I really like the flavour too.
It steals a body form an uncast creature, and then, upon death, splits open to reveal something much nastier inside it.

Very nice.
I do, however, weep over the length of the rules text.
Imagine the flavour text you could have on a card called Body Snatcher!

4.5/5

15189: Body Snatcher.author: BobbySinclair
15189: Body Snatcher.text_parsed: Wow, amazing card that filled the hole in my Kresh the Bloodbraid sac deck. Gets cards into your graveyard, from your graveyard, provides some control against aggro players, and is very well costed! Even more than that, you can avoid discarding a creature if you don't have one by sac'ing it to something like Ashnod's Altar before it exiles, AND you can avoid it getting exiled when it hits the graveyard with undying and persist effects, or returning it to your library or hand with cards such as Volrath's Stronghold! Add in a Strionic resonator and other such things, and you'll have a powerhouse reanimation card that will see you dropping Eldrazi from at most turn 4 with a decont sac outlet!

15193: Yawgmoth's Bargain.author: DoctorKenneth
15193: Yawgmoth's Bargain.text_parsed:
It's time for commenting on the comments again! Huzzah! Lets dip into the mailbag and see what we have...

Gilgamesh3000 asks: "What's happening in the art?"

Well, Gilgamesh, thanks for taking the time away from ruling ancient kingdoms to comment on this card. Taking a look at the art, I'd wager it's some kind of bargain. Some kind of bargain with Yawgmoth.

benzensulfonic writes: "Ok, let's say I'm a noob who just got into MTG.... How is this card (and Necropotence for that matter) helpful to you?"

Let me put it like this. Your life total is generally the primary obstacle your opponent must overcome in order to win the game. Knowing this, new players feel it's important above all else to protect this life total. In effect, they are mostly correct. But there is a saying among the more experienced players that "the only life point that matters is the last one." That is to say, while it is more perilous to be at 3 life than 20 (what with Lightning Bolts flying around), if you are in a position to defend yourself, it shouldn't matter. What I'm getting at here, is that life is a semi-expendable resource. Experienced players gladly take the hits from their painlands (lands that deal damage to you) to fix their mana. Since early on in the game, players poured their life into Channel and its ilk to win just a little bit faster. The concept is a little more in-depth than that, but you get the point.

The most valuable resource in this game is card advantage. Lets say you have a spell that reads "Counter target spell. Draw a card". This means that, when using it, you have used one of your cards to negate one of your opponents cards. Plus, you have replaced the spell you just played with a new card. You have lost nothing, in effect, but your opponent has lost something. You have then gained card advantage over your opponent. Spells like Blightning and other discard effects have always been popular because they create this advantage; and card drawing effects are popular for the same reason. When a player has run out of spells in their hand, their options are vastly reduced. The player with more cards available has more control over the state of the board, while the top-decking player has to rely more heavily on the state of the board they have already set up. So in effect, Yawgmoth's Bargain creates a huge amount of this card advantage. You lose nothing of great value, but you get a card. With that, you can be sure that you have a steady flow of creatures, removal, and other such things, when your opponent(s) are "out of gas", so to speak. The bargain doesn't "win you the game" on it's own. It's what's called an "engine"- a card that enables other cards to work more effectively for you. When played early with Dark Ritual, this will undoubtably get you the means of winning the game. It will draw you more cards than many new players would expect. More cards equals stronger position.

Hope that helped!

15193: Yawgmoth's Bargain.author: jfre81
15193: Yawgmoth's Bargain.text_parsed:
Necropotence vs. Yawgmoth's Bargain.

Necropotence can get played on first turn with Dark Ritual
Yawgmoth's Bargain could get out on first turn with two Rituals plus something that gives you at least one free mana, e.g. Lotus Petal or Mox Jet.
Advantage: Necropotence. I'd prefer to save the Rituals for playing something drawn with it rather than getting the enchantment out on first turn.

Necropotence is not card drawing - the cards are coming from the exile zone - so it does not work with Archmage Ascension. Yawgmoth's Bargain is card drawing, so it does work with it, and you can hit it on someone else's turn to rack up the counters. Soon, it's pay one life for Demonic Tutor. Wicked.
Advantage: Yawgmoth's Bargain.

Necropotence and Yawgmoth's Bargain both fall to any enchantment removal and black doesn't have much of an answer for it. This is why I've never considered either one truly broken, just highly powerful and highly characteristic of black.
Advantage: Draw.

You can't go wrong with either one.

15193: Yawgmoth's Bargain.author: Number3124
15193: Yawgmoth's Bargain.text_parsed:
Love this card. This + Psychosis Crawler + Skirge Familiar + Ivory Tower + Exsanguinate = win.

Just wait until the end of your opponent(s) turn, draw cards equal to all but one of your life total. If the Crawler doesn't kill them, then you get back all but four of your life at the beginning of your turn, then discard every card in your hand but Exsanguinate with Skirge and cast for the win. Works every time. If you want a laugh then pair this card with Mycosynth Lattice and Darksteel Forge to let people freak out at how their enchantment removal is now worthless. Best engine ever for us combo-happy Johnys out there.

15193: Yawgmoth's Bargain.author: DarthParallax
15193: Yawgmoth's Bargain.text_parsed:
GRISELBRAND

LEGENDARY DEMON

7/7 FLYING LIFELINK

PAY 7 LIFE: DRAW 7 CARDS


let's review:

Legendary Creature versus Enchantment...interesting. He's the kind of creature you'll really want to give some kind of equipment to anyway, so he's probably LESS removable than Bargain, since he already has 'poor man's protection from Black' (being Black), so adding, say, Sword of War and Peace...yeah that'll be good :)

The life loss is 1/3 of Standard starting lifetotal, but ~1/6 of Commander starting total. And you pay it all at once, rather than 1 at a time. In 60-card play, Bargain MIGHT seem more versatile....

LIFELINK. 7 POWER. ACTUALLY, YOU SHOULD BE DRAWING THE CARDS "FOR FREE".
oh.
OH.

Damn.

Griselbrand isn't 'strictly' better than this card---except in Kaalia of the Vast.

In Kaalia of the Vast, Yawgmoth's Bargain costs you 0 mana and 0 life and you don't have to skip your draw step, but you do get to smash for 7 in the air. Griselbrand is probably more powerful than Necropotence in Kaalia's Deck.

adrian.malacoda: So Yawgmoth's Bargain and Griselbrand are both Banned in Commander. I think this simply proves my point that Griselbrand is at least as mighty if not more than Yawgmoth's Bargain.
And Griselbrand is not Banned in Legacy, yet, and is makng lots of noise over there. Wierdly, it would be easier to get Griselbrand into play than Bargain, even if Bargain were Legal there. Being faster to get on the battlefield AND much more powerful with the lifelink thing, it must be just a stupidly huge deal in Legacy that Griselbrand Dies To Plowshares.

From now on, I'm giving every card spoiled that doesn't Die To Plowshares an extra 1.5 Stars, and an extra .2 Stars after that if it doesn't Die to Bolt. So every noncreature is an automatic 1.7 Stars, and a creature that doesn't Die to either gets 2 full stars of 'bump'.

15193: Yawgmoth's Bargain.author: Enelysios
15193: Yawgmoth's Bargain.text_parsed:
This isn't just a necropotence that costs twice as much. It has some advantages in that you actually just draw the cards at instant speed and more importantly you can discard to fuel Yawgmoth's will or reanimation or whatever else you need a graveyard for.

As for Bargain Vs Griselbrand, yes, Bargain is better, but not 'strictly better'. Griselbrand is a creature, a rather meaty creature that is useful whenever creatures are useful. He is easier to reanimate for a dredge deck, he works as a way to kill your opponent. Plus, you don't skip your draw step. On the downside, he costs more and you have to buy your draws in batches of 7. He is a different card and both are good. Hell, both are exceptional. There is no reason that both can't be useful.

15193: Yawgmoth's Bargain.author: blurrymadness
15193: Yawgmoth's Bargain.text_parsed:
@jfre81
The reason they're broken isn't because they can be destroyed; it's that in destroying them your opponent responds by paying life, drawing cards, and winning next turn anyway. The only counters to this card are counterspells.

Combo cards like this aren't there to slowly increase your draw like a Dark Confidant, they explosively draw the top huge-amount of your library and allow you to win on the spot. The idea that this is balanced by enchantment removal implies that Ad Nauseam is better; which is hard to swallow. That card is awesome; but mostly because it's the best in the format at what it does; and not because it's a non-enchantment.

15193: Yawgmoth's Bargain.author: TheKazu
15193: Yawgmoth's Bargain.text_parsed:
Please look at this.

People talk about the {B}{B} difference between this and griselbrand. It seriously doesn't even matter. Nobody ever hardcasts griselbrand. It just means that rather than requiring (another) Dark Ritual as a combo piece to get this thing out at a reasonable point in time, you're going to be needing a Reanimate or the like.

What you're giving up with griselbrand is the ability to incrementally draw, which is kind of a big deal. But you're getting something which is just as big of a deal, and that is a win condition that on the very next turn will make up for your loss of life. They need to try this card in Legacy again.

actually, I like this card a lot :)

it's 3 power for 3 mana! that's not too pushed, but it IS a big enough change to shake up limited somewhat. and it's fire-resistant (limited red removal will usually have a tough time getting rid of it).

'can't block' makes an interesting board-- but at the same time, not 'too' interesting, bc imho I can see myself blocking with white, green and even blue creatures (turtles? magic walls? heck ya!) before I want to be blocking with red creatures. the only color I want to block with less than red is black, because I want my black creatures to be so stupid that they win the game for me when they enter the battlefield, before they even get a chance to attack. See Griselbrand, lol.

15196: Hulking Ogre.author: Jannissary
15196: Hulking Ogre.text_parsed:
Kind of in a thorny spot. Not being able to block sucks, but it'd be too strong at 1R. What it should have been is 3/2 for 1R and can't block, or 4/3 at 2R and can't block. Something halfway in between, to make it a good beater that has very real downsides.

Unleash proved that being unable to block is worth +1/+1, and even then it's sometimes not even worth it. Blocking is really important.

15216: Repercussion.author: Japicx
15216: Repercussion.text_parsed:
In a five-player EDH game, I took down three people at once by playing Chain Reaction with this in play. The guy before had just played a kicked Rite of Replication, which boosted the creature count to 15, dealing over 100 damage to some of them. I actually lost the game to the one guy who survived, but even though I didn't win, that play won. Also, use with Earthquake or Starstorm to kill off token decks.

It's also handy in that it makes blocking pretty much pointless. Also, if you block a creature with trample, you'll end up taking more damage than if you didn't block at all. I smell a janky force-block combo...

NO! You won't take more damage than an attacking trample creature's power by blocking it. You will take exactly it's power. Whatever was done to the creature plus the damage that went directly to the defending player.

Attacking with this card out is dangerous since your creatures are going to take damage, and so will you.
This card is one of the easier ways to create a draw.

Disaster Radius is even more nuts than flamewave, since it will hit all of your opponents, and quite likely for more than 4 damage.

15216: Repercussion.author: Neilendil
15216: Repercussion.text_parsed:
Easily my favourite card. Staples that I haven't seen mentioned here include Forbidden Orchard, Swans of Bryn Argol, and Bloodfire Colossus which is an absolute MONSTER sitting around just waiting for someone to make a move against you. 6 damage to each non-flying creature for 1 red mana is the greatest protection for your Repercussion.

I have toyed with Mana Flare to help achieve that Bloodfire Colossus and also Purity. Though I haven't had much use or success out of the latter.

Chain Reaction and Blasphemous Act are all the burn you could ever need. Varchild's War Riders are hard to beat for token generation, as are the Hunted creatures.

Repercussion puts such a huge target on your head. I'm looking at making the deck more group friendly with Heartbeat of Spring, Rites of Flourishing and Eladamri's Vineyard.

15217: Impatience.author: leomistico
15217: Impatience.text_parsed:
@scumbling1: no, it's not win-more... "If your opponent isn't casting spells, it is very likely that they're losing.": who told you that?
It's actually an anti-permission card. If your opponent plays permission deck, then he would be quite often in draw-go mode, so would take 2 damages from this card every turn. This card is a sideboard against that deck...

I like very much red cards that forces players to some action that actually ends in some lose-lose situations, like Antagonism, Fumiko the Lowblood, Citadel of Pain/Stoneshaker Shaman, Grand Melee, Heat of Battle (Battle Strain), War's Toll...

This + Forced Fruition = brain explosion...

4/5

I like very much red cards that forces players to some action that actually ends in some lose-lose situations, like [autocard]Antagonism[/autocard], [autocard]Fumiko the Lowblood[/autocard], [autocard]Citadel of Pain[/autocard]/[autocard]Stoneshaker Shaman[/autocard], [autocard]Grand Melee[/autocard], [autocard]Heat of Battle[/autocard] ([autocard]Battle Strain[/autocard]), [autocard]War's Toll[/autocard]...

This + [autocard]Forced Fruition[/autocard] = brain explosion...

4/5

15218: Wake of Destruction.author: igniteice
15218: Wake of Destruction.text_parsed: I dislike land destruction as much as the next person -- nothing worse than having someone use a strip mine on your best land in the first few turns to completely stall you, but some decks need to have land destroyed. You either take out the Emeria, the Sky Ruin, or you run this and take out all the plains, and I've had opponents with a full set of four Emerias on the board. The same is true for a number of cards that revolve around how many lands you have, and most of them are mono-colored decks, especially green (turn all your forests into 2/2s, or creatures whose power/toughness is dependent on forest count). Wake of Destruction is absolutely necessary and fair in these cases.

15219: Hunting Moa.author: majinara
15219: Hunting Moa.text_parsed:
That guy ain't bad.
Without echo you have a wall for one turn and can divide two +1/+1 counters on your creatures. If you pay echo, you got a decent sized guy and the +1/+1 counters. Also good with any creatures that can make good use of +1/+1 counters (like Fertilid or Triskelionfor example). Also fun in decks with persist, since you can use the counters from this guy to remove the -1/-1 counters from guys of yours which persisted.

Not incredible, but has it's uses.

15224: Ivy Seer.author: NARFNra
15224: Ivy Seer.text_parsed:
I now present the very lowest rated card in Urza's Block. Let's see why:

Horrible P/T to cost ratio:
1/1 to {3}{G} is sad. We're talking Chimney Imp level. Not to mention it costs as much as Might Of Oaks.

Low Powered Ability:
The ability has the POTENTIAL to give you +7/+7 or more. But really, who runs Card Draw Green? And why use that when you can use, oh, Giant Growth for a way more dependable boost?

Oh, and it tells your opponent what you're able to play.

Ability is overcosted:
{2}{G}? Really? And it even taps so you can't multiuse it? Hmph. Remember that's the cost of 3 Giant Growths people.

Uncommon Rarity:
Just another way to make people sigh when they open their (8 cards at the time) packs.

At least it has a usable creature type.

15225: Yavimaya Elder.author: Plum
15225: Yavimaya Elder.text_parsed:
Damn... this is pure card advantage for green.
Pump this out turn 2, and get an extra 3 cards in your hand turn 3. If your opponent bolts him you still get the free lands.
Once he's on the field you could hit him with Swords to Plowshares or Path to Exile. And if you do that you are still giving your opponent some sort of advantage. If you have two mana, you could sac him in response and get the draw anyway. So it kind of reads: If you don't counter this card, your opponent is going to get ahead of you no matter what.

15234: Pattern of Rebirth.author: Brawler_1337
15234: Pattern of Rebirth.text_parsed: I put this card in my Uril EDH deck, and I gotta say that I love it. Opening up with it and either a self-sacrificing creature like Yavimaya Elder or Sakura-Tribe Elder or a sacrifice engine like Greater Good or Greater Gargadon usually means an early Ulamog, the Infinite Gyre or looping shenanigans with Sun Titan, Nomad Mythmaker and/or Eternal Witness, and this card. And if you don't have that, you can always play it on a creature to force people to think twice about nuking the board until they can deal with the creature that comes out. It's even better when your opponents can't target it thanks to Sterling Grove. This is definitely one of my favorite non-combat Auras.

15237: Rofellos, Llanowar Emissary.text_parsed:
Urza's block - even after all these years, Wizards still had no idea what it was doing.

First turn - Forest, Llanowar Elves. Alright... that's not too bad.

Second turn - Tap both for Priest of Titania; play Gaea's Cradle, tap for Rofellos. Hrmmm....

Third turn - A second forest means access to 11 mana. Wait, what?

What are you even going to do with that much mana? Play a Joraga Warcaller with 5 kickers? Follow up with an Immaculate Magistrate and a couple Imperious Perfects? Having fun yet?

15237: Rofellos, Llanowar Emissary.author: LeakyBucket
15237: Rofellos, Llanowar Emissary.text_parsed:
You guys are using this card all wrong. If you are running mono green there is no way you shouldn't get a Verdant Force out on turn two in the best case. And be more than unpleasant for your opponent in the average case.

Forest + Elvish Spirit Guide = Gaea's Touch
Play an extra Forest
sac Gaea's Touch to play another Gaea's Touch
Play and extra Forest
Tap two forests to play Rofellos

Turn two
Rofellos + Three Forests + sac Gaea's Touch = Verdant Force.

For those asking why they printed this in the first place. There was a time in this game when you had to pay more attention to what you were doing and plan ahead. Since they've gotten rid of mana burn this card has become a no-brainer. It didn't used to be that way. It could backfire on you big time if you tapped for a ton then the target for your mana died. Ooopps that's 10 damage from mana, thanks Rofellos.

15237: Rofellos, Llanowar Emissary.author: GoofyAce
15237: Rofellos, Llanowar Emissary.text_parsed: Turn One, Forest+Joraga Treespeaker. Turn Two, Forest+ Gaea's Touch into another forest, Sacrifice Gaea's Touch, level Joraga Treespeaker, tap for Rofellos, Llanowar Emissary, use the last mana for Instill Energy. Now that may be 7 cards already but 11 mana on turn 2 with 6 still available for whatever those 1 or 2 cards you have left are is not too bad, but as long as I'm indulging in this pipe dream let's say you play a Harmonize for draw and then plonk down a Priest of Titania with the remaining 2 mana. Now you not only have 1 or 2 cards STILL remaining but you have 14 mana by the end of turn two...that's silly; now to finish off this dream let's say your remaining two cards (you went second) are a forest and Emrakul, the Aeons Torn; put down the forest (now you have 16 mana turn 3 without tapping anything) and play Emrakul, but not before you spend that one mana on an Essence Warden that you drew this turn :) Turn 3 Emrakul without any banned cards is nothing to scoff at and I'm sure you could make a more ridiculous combo. This card might be ok.

15237: Rofellos, Llanowar Emissary.author: Ragamander
15237: Rofellos, Llanowar Emissary.text_parsed:
@Nate_Prawdzik: Why stop at just a third-turn Emrakul, the Aeons Torn?

T1: Play Forest, cast Exploration, play another Forest, cast Concordant Crossroads. (Cards remaining = 3)
T2: Draw a card for the turn, play 2x Forest, cast Rofellos, Llanowar Emissary and tap it for , cast Primeval Titan (for 2x Wirewood Lodge) and attack with it (for another 2x Wirewood Lodge). (Cards remaining = 0)
T3: Draw a card for the turn, attack with Primeval Titan (for 2x Forest), tap 4x Forest and Rofellos, Llanowar Emissary for a total of , cast Kozilek, Butcher of Truth and draw 4 cards, play 2x Forest and tap them to float , with 4x untapped Wirewood Lodge remaining...
Untap Rofellos, Llanowar Emissary and tap it, floating (9),
Untap Rofellos, Llanowar Emissary and tap it, floating (16),
Untap Rofellos, Llanowar Emissary and tap it, floating (23),
Untap Rofellos, Llanowar Emissary and tap it, floating (30),
Cast Spawnsire of Ulamog and activate its ultimate ability, casting (in the following order): 3x Skittering Invasion, 4x Broodwarden, 3x Emrakul, the Aeons Torn, 3x Ulamog, the Infinite Gyre, 1x All Is Dust, 1x It That Betrays, putting 3x "take an extra turn" triggers and 3x "destroy target permanent" triggers onto the stack; then resolve everything (in reverse order, of course).

On your third turn, you destroy 3 permanents, then force them to sacrifice all their colored permanents (of which you gain control!), then take three extra turns with a board position that includes Annihilator 17 and 191 damage from your Eldrazi alone, not to mention all the colored permanents they used to control. And you've already attacked for 12 with your Primeval Titan.

There's no kill like overkill.

15237: Rofellos, Llanowar Emissary.author: kridily
15237: Rofellos, Llanowar Emissary.text_parsed:
@Ragamander: Oh jeeze that's hilarious! And it got me thinking. You can totally do this on turn two without having to put in any cheeky cards that aren't good for anything but the combo, but only if you're on the draw, or playing multiplayer (or otherwise have 10 cards in hand), though it abuses an infinite combo if you don't like that sort of thing, because Rofellos plus equipment that untaps him (Umbral Mantle, Sword of the Paruns) is totally broke:

T1: Draw a card for the turn, Play Forest, cast Exploration, play another Forest, cast Concordant Crossroads. (Cards remaining = 4)
T2: Draw a card for the turn, play 2x Forest, cast Rofellos, Llanowar Emissary, then tap him and cast Umbral Mantle for , floating , then equip the mantle to Rofellos for , and tap the remaining 2 Forests and use the floating mana to activate its ability. Then tap and untap Rofellos, and tap and untap, and tap and untap... until you have an essentially infinite amount of green mana, and a hasty Rofellos with essentially inifinite power and toughness. With your remaining card, cast Spawnsire of Ulamog and activate its ultimate ability to dump your Eldrazi tub on the table as you so elegantly laid out in the rest of that comment.

I know this and much much worse is possible turn one as well, but not with an Azusa deck (what I'm looking into now for EDH), it'd need to be a specially engineered turn one win deck. If someone can figure this out on turn one with a proper Azusa EDH deck (commander legal cards), I'd love to see it.

15241: Elvish Piper.author: OlvynChuru
15241: Elvish Piper.text_parsed: Urza Block ended up having SO many cards that got out big scary effects really quickly (either by adding a lot of mana or by cheating things into play). See Tolarian Academy, Gaea's Cradle, Serra's Sanctum, Metalworker, Bubbling Muck, Defense of the Heart, Pattern of Rebirth, Gamekeeper, Academy Rector, Quicksilver Amulet, Tinker, Exploration, Show and Tell, Priest of Titania, Goblin Welder, Sneak Attack, Goblin Lackey, Rofellos, Copper Gnomes, this card, and more. Elvish Piper is one of the few of those that ended up being good instead of overpowered, and that's why I like it. It's also one of those cards that new players tend to overvalue and experienced players tend to undervalue. Yes, it is vulnerable to removal, yet it is less so than Metalworker, which is widely considered to be overpowered (I'm not at all saying that Metalworker is not overpowered; in fact, it IS more powerful than the piper). Also, remember that if you manage to cheat a Progenitus or something like that into play, you WILL most likely win.

15246: Metalworker.author: Malnourished_Student
15246: Metalworker.text_parsed:
@Tera_GX
It's not as unfair as you'd think. Not only do you need this card, but you also have to have had it on the board for a whole turn to get over the summoning sickness. Then, you need to get a Voltaic Construct down too. Additionally, you still need at least 2 artifacts in your hand AND some way of using the mana. So you're talking a pretty card-intensive combo there!
To be fair, I use this combo in a Memnarch Control deck, and it's awesome when it goes off (still need blue mana though) and you take your opponents side of the board for yourself. It can work, but I assure you, keeping one of these alive long enough to fire it off is not so simple.

15246: Metalworker.author: reapersaurus
15246: Metalworker.text_parsed:
After playing with this card in an UrzaTron deck with huge artifacts, this card is absolutely a joke.
Once it hits the table and is used, the amount of mana he generates is SO out-of-balance with the game of Magic, I'm shocked any Magic designer couldn't see this during the design phase, much less the playtesting phase.

If this card simply generated ONE mana per card revealed, he STILL would be broken, but it would be workable, and at least comparable to the other absurd mana-generating creatures and land (Tolarian Academy, Rofollos, and Gaea's Cradle excepted).
15246: Metalworker.text_posted:

If this card simply generated ONE mana per card revealed, he STILL would be broken, but it would be workable, and at least comparable to the other absurd mana-generating creatures and land (Tolarian Academy, Rofollos, and Gaea's Cradle excepted).

15257: Urza's Incubator.author: Ferlord
15257: Urza's Incubator.text_parsed:
Watch out which tribal you're planning on playing it in. Elves may seem like a tribe that needs this, but remember that lots of them don't have much colourless mana (llanowar Elves, Rofellos, Llanowar Emissary, Joraga Warcaller, Heritage Druid, etc.).

Probably the best tribes for this are Slivers and Myrs. Slivers aren't usually colour-heavy (except for Sliver Legion, Sliver Overlord and Sliver Queen), and Myr's... well, I think it's quite obvious when you're able to play Myr Superion for .

Also, remember who you're playing against and what type you choose. If you choose Human, your opponents are bound to have some of their own.

15257: Urza's Incubator.author: NissasChosen
15257: Urza's Incubator.text_parsed:
"Awesome in a tribal deck but unless you buy craploads of boosters to make a themed deck (for example a Merfolk deck or an Elf deck) it's about as useful as Strength of Unity would be in a mono-color deck"
Are you joking? Have you not heard of buying singles?
Ok, a bit of advice to everyone. You, through this database, have access to information on every MTG card ever printed. You can then playtest these decks on Magic Workstation, ***atrice, and several other programs, post them and get advice on MTG Salvation, Tapped Out, or any of the other forums, and repeat until you have a working deck, all without spending a penny. Then you can order the Cards from TCGPlayer , Star City Games, ChannelFireball, Blackborder, or any of the other sites. If you want immediacy, go to your local card store. Don't know where your local card store is? Look up FNM locations on this site, most FNM locations are card stores.
The only times I or anyone I play with even opens packs are sealed events and prizes.
Seriously, if you are at all finance concerned, buying packs usually provides little to no return on investment, and will almost never get you all of what you need for a solid deck. Buy singles. If you're new, buy intro packs and event decks, until you get an idea of how to build. Never buy boosters unless you just hate money.

Oh, right, the card. One of my friends runs it in his Giant Tribal. Good for any high-curve tribe. Very win-more in Elves, Vampires, Zombies, Merfolk or any other low-curve tribes. All in all solid if a bit limited in use. 3.5/5

@Mattmedia "Ratchet Bomb kind of makes this a little redundant...."

No, it doesn't. Both have same speedcards have its uses. Ratchet bomb hits Enchantments and Planeswalkers, while Powder keg hits Creature lands, Manlands and Artifact lands. Also, the fact that it leaves Enchantments alone can be built around. You can run a Discard deck with Shrieking affliction instead of The Rack and be safe from it's effect entirely.

15261: Aura Thief.author: OutlawD1
15261: Aura Thief.text_parsed: Basically you get to control or change what the enchantment or aura does. You can deny opponents their auras that require activated abilities to be effective. Auras with static and triggered abilities won't really matter, unless they affect "you" somehow. Regular enchantments are usually static, but also usually penalize your "opponent" and benefit "you" (the controller).

15261: Aura Thief.author: sonorhC
15261: Aura Thief.text_parsed:
Examples of auras for which it matters who controls them:
Firebreathing: The activated ability is on the enchantment, not on the creature, so you decide whether to pump up the enchanted creature (and will presumably decide not to).
Control Magic: It says "you control enchanted creature", and who "you" is changes. So in this case you'd steal the creature, too.
Vow of Wildness: The "you" in "can't attack you" is the enchantment's controller, so now that creature can't attack you, but can attack whomever the previous controller was.
Prison Term: The controller is the one who decides whether to move it to a new creature.

Examples of auras for which it doesn't matter:
Unholy Strength, Rancor, Power of Fire, Arrest
15261: Aura Thief.text_posted:

[autocard]Control Magic[/autocard]:  It says "you control enchanted creature", and who "you" is changes.  So in this case you'd steal the creature, too.
[autocard]Vow of Wildness[/autocard]:  The "you" in "can't attack you" is the enchantment's controller, so now that creature can't attack you, but can attack whomever the previous controller was.

15263: Scent of Jasmine.author: raptorman333
15263: Scent of Jasmine.text_parsed:
completely underrated. for one mana in a mono white deck you can essentially gain 14 life. heroes' reunion sees more love than this because for 1 green mana more you don't have to reveal anything, don't need cards in your hand and they don't have to be white either. also heals your allies. but there's some key factors to that--you need green mana and it costs 1 more. this is an early turn bomb or the upper hand during a multiplayer stall. i've seen this used by my friend countless times and every time it become a gigantic pain in the ass to knock down the ten life he just gained while his tempo didn't get disrupted because it only cost 1 mana. 3/5

i agree with sonorhC though. i'd rather play martyr of sands. but this was around before that and i never played cold snap.

15765: False Prophet.author: BegleOne
15765: False Prophet.text_parsed:
They're exiled not because their bodies can't be found, but because their souls have been so deluded with false conviction that they can never bond with reality again... The prophet has taken their spirits, but nobody knows where.

I don't think I've ever had a card excite me like this guy. You can use him in a combo/ control deck; just get rid of him as soon as you play him using Altar of Bone, Mask of the Mimic, Scapegoat (if you can convince your opponent that works in your advantage), et cetera. You can use him in an enchantment or equipment heavy aggressive deck; if somebody does get rid of your guy with three equipments and two auras on him, they get rid of their army as well. Just having him on the table as a blocker works in your favor; people don't want to attack when your chump blocker obliterates their whole field when he dies.

Against most any deck that wins with creatures, this is a single card that can shut down five, ten, twenty of theirs. It's a little expensive and it keeps you from running lots of creatures yourself, but with imagination he's a Peacekeeper, Wrath of God, Moat and more all rolled into one. Love this card.

15768: Chime of Night.author: MisterAction
15768: Chime of Night.text_parsed:
Compared to other kill spells, your opponent sees this coming a mile away, but that doesn't make it strictly worse.

This is a handy deterrent in a multiplayer game. They don't know when you're holding a doom blade, but they know that if they attack you, you'll trade with one of their creatures and take out another one too. Much less hassle for them to attack each other while you build up power.

15768: Chime of Night.author: Cyberium
15768: Chime of Night.text_parsed:
This is a tactical card. If you see it strictly as a creature removal then it's definitely not as good as many other options in black, such as Doom Blade.

However, know that this is a creature enchantment that you can put on your creature. If you have a good creature in play that you want to keep alive, enchant it with Chime would make killing it a more difficult choice. In multiplayer game this also adds a lot more politics to it, meddling with other players' creatures.

Also, being an enchantment there are a good variety of ways in putting it directly into play. Once it's in play you no longer have to hold mana open as you would with Doom Blade. Academy Rector, Monk Idealist, Replenish are just some examples of how to further abuse Chime of Night's power.

15769: Tethered Griffin.author: blurrymadness
15769: Tethered Griffin.text_parsed:
@Taravits
The reason is because Maro doesn't get to check his toughness. This thing says "Oh wait, you have no enchantments? Let me put my 'sacrifice me' ability on the stack :D:D:D:D!", Maro would need priority to die (which means you have cards in hand again) and Barren Glory is an IF clause, not a Whenever clause; meaning there's a condition it has to meet upon resolution.

This says "when this, do this", meaning it doesn't need to check on resolution. One triggers on the event (this), one triggers at another time and checks the condition (glory), and one checks the current condition whenever someone checks state based effects (maro)

15770: Covetous Dragon.author: blurrymadness
15770: Covetous Dragon.text_parsed:
@Taravits
This is a triggered ability, Maro's is a state-based ability. State-based abilities are checked as priority is given to players, triggered abilities go on the stack as soon as the event happens.

May have worded that slightly off, but that's the general idea.

I.E. -You have this and you Polymorph your artifact creature (your only artifact.) Polymorph starts resolving and destroys your last artifact, this guy's ability goes on the stack. You finish resolving Polymorph and then go to this guy's ability. Whether or not you found an artifact card is no longer relevant; this guy put the ability on the stack:
"Sacrifice this creature." The ability is NOT "Sacrifice this creature if you have no artifacts", it's "When."

Because of all this you're stuck losing him if you EVER hit 0 artifacts.

15770: Covetous Dragon.author: EvilDarkVoid
15770: Covetous Dragon.text_parsed: @Tavaritz: The difference is that Covetous Dragon has a triggered ability to tell you to sacrifice it, while Maro's ability merely changes its toughness. If I play Polymorph on an artifact creature when its the only one I control, then I temporarily control no artifacts and so the dragon's sacrifice trigger activates. I can get another artifact creature off of the Polymorph but it won't help since his sacrifice trigger is already on the stack. If I use a Wheel of Fortune effect while I have a Maro creature out, Maro's toughness would become 0 after I discard my hand but before I draw a new one. However, creatures don't get sent to the graveyard for having 0 toughness during the resolution of an effect, and by the time the Wheel of Fortune finishes resolving I have cards in my hand again so its toughness is greater than 0.
15770: Covetous Dragon.text_posted: @Tavaritz: The difference is that [autocard]Covetous Dragon[/autocard] has a triggered ability to tell you to sacrifice it, while [autocard]Maro[/autocard]'s ability merely changes its toughness. If I play [autocard]Polymorph[/autocard] on an artifact creature when its the only one I control, then I temporarily control no artifacts and so the dragon's sacrifice trigger activates. I can get another artifact creature off of the Polymorph but it won't help since his sacrifice trigger is already on the stack. If I use a [autocard]Wheel of Fortune[/autocard] effect while I have a [autocard]Maro[/autocard] creature out, Maro's toughness would become 0 after I discard my hand but before I draw a new one. However, creatures don't get sent to the graveyard for having 0 toughness during the resolution of an effect, and by the time the Wheel of Fortune finishes resolving I have cards in my hand again so its toughness is greater than 0.

15771: Goblin Festival.author: leomistico
15771: Goblin Festival.text_parsed:
First thing, best flavour text ever!
Second, like hid@n said, you have to stack the ability so you have to deal as much damage as you can and then pass the enchantment. If the opponent lose because of it, it doesn't matter the whole coin game... Obviously, you have to have infinite mana (or a very large number), but it works, and goes around a lot of prevention effects, like the Circle of Protection: Red. And, Gabbalis, why you should replace it with goblin cannon? If you have a infinite mana engine, 2 mana doesn't make any difference, and like I've said, if the opponent dies either side effect doesn't matter. However, this is much more funnier in multiplayer games. Only reason that comes in mind is that the cannon is colorless, but being an artifact is easier to destroy, if you have to wait a little to complete the combo.
I'd play this before cannon without any thought.
4/5

15772: Yavimaya Hollow.author: humor_love
15772: Yavimaya Hollow.text_parsed:
Playing this land is similar to playing Regeneration without paying it's casting cost - except that the regeneration can be performed only once for each time the land is tapped, and the regeneration can be applied to any creature in play. Regeneration enchants one creature and its effect applies to that one creature only.

This card's pretty cool. It's not a staple, but it can be useful. It's better in slower games or in games of larger scale than one-on-one. Uh ... I give it a 2.5 of 5.

15773: Emperor Crocodile.author: OffensiveBias
15773: Emperor Crocodile.text_parsed: @tavaritz: The reason is that state-based effects, like a creature being put into a graveyard for having zero power, are only checked before players get priority, i.e. after each spell/ability is put onto or removed from the stack. This guy's ability is a triggered ability, so it triggers in the middle of other spells' resolution (such as Momentary Blink).

15784: Sigil of Sleep.author: jsttu
15784: Sigil of Sleep.text_parsed: i have fun enchanting Karplusan Wolverine with this. If they block i ping the player and bounce the blocker before damage, and if they do not block i get to bounce a creature of my choice. Putting it on a prodigal sorcerer probably works better, but my way presents them with a dilemma to make them squirm. Best of all this can occur turn two, bouncing your opponents first creature and preventing them from having more than one in the future unless they cast them simultaneously, meanwhile netting you a lot of tempo and card advantage. If you cannot win with that you built the wrong deck.

15875: Temporal Adept.author: Hovercraft
15875: Temporal Adept.text_parsed: Time Elemental is better. Consider playing it with Ancient Tomb, and Chrome Mox. People used to bounce their Stasis at the end of their own turn so they could untap their own lands, and then play it again. With Temporal Adept, take into account the amount of colored mana you would need to make it useful. Time Elemental splashes way nicelier with Wasteland or Rishadan Port . Honestly... maybe seems strange at first but Temporal Adept is pretty weaksauce and falls prey to the ping too. You can't really attack with Time Elemental.. but who cares. Your win condition could easily be something else like Jace, The Mind Sculptor... Time Elemental should be played with Amnesia for Br00tal games.

15875: Temporal Adept.author: TDL
15875: Temporal Adept.text_parsed:
@Hovercraft:
Time Elemental? Seriously? Temporal Adept has one less toughness and has a more intensive blue mana requirement, but so what? If you're running a heavy combo deck and Temporal Adept is part of it, then you're either an idiot or protecting the Adept and making sure you can cast it! One more toughness might save the Elemental from pinging, but odds are if your opponent has one pinger, they'll have more. Shock kills both the Adept and the Elemental, and it has even been replaced by the more powerful Lightning Bolt!
As for the blue mana requirement, you can either go mono blue, rendering the point moot, or you can shore up your mana base with fetch lands, dual lands, and even artifacts like Darksteel Ingot. It's not that difficult.
Also, don't forget that if your opponent has enchanted something with say, Rancor, the Adept isn't completely helpless to do anything about it.

15876: Goblin Berserker.author: Aquillion
15876: Goblin Berserker.text_parsed:
Even with Goblin Lackey, he sucks; you're not getting to use his Haste in that case, so he becomes a ridiculously overcosted 2/2 first striker.

(Yes, Goblin Lackey bypasses his cost; but the idea behind a card like Goblin Lackey is that you want cards that are playable and decent without your Lackey, while being overwhelmingly powerful when dropped with it. This card is barely decent with the lackey, and useless without it. Terrible! Just use a Goblin King or the like instead.)

15877: Rofellos's Gift.author: HuntingDrake
15877: Rofellos's Gift.text_parsed:
Could've made for a fun casual deck back in 1999.
In Urza Block: Defense of the Heart, Pattern of Rebirth, Midsummer Revel, War Dance, some good buffing Auras, and Hidden Ancients, Gibbons, Guerrillas, Herd, Predators, Spider, and Stag.
In Tempest Block before it: Frog Tongue, Bequeathal.
In Masques Block after it: Ancestral Mask, FOSTER, Lure, Vernal Equinox, Saproling Burst, Seal of Strength, Living Terrain.

Also Argothian Enchantress, Hermit Druid, Multani, Maro-Sorcerer, Endless Wurm, Verdant Force, Yavimaya Enchantress, Titania's Chosen, and some other sweet fatties and mana elves.

18287: Tormented Angel.author: sarroth
18287: Tormented Angel.text_parsed:
Vigilance would be nice, so you can neatly attack and still have your big-butted blocker available. Then if you pump her with equipment or enchantments, she's that much better.

As for her being tormented, I asked the same thing when I compared this card to Wayward Angel on the latter card's page, and izzet_guild_mage explained that she is tormented by the destruction of Serra's Realm by Phyrexia, and her fall from heaven is having to leave the realm to survive. That explanation makes the flavor make much more sense to me, but still this card leaves a sour presence where the flavor could have been on a card worth a slot in a dedicated casual Angel deck. As such, there is great flavor and good art crap.

19097: Illuminated Wings.author: DarthParallax
19097: Illuminated Wings.text_parsed:
This actually isn't bad. I'm not sure how useful it is, but it has "Cycling from Play" which is an ability that a few Urza's Destiny cards have, notably Plague Dogs and Yavimaya Elder. The important thing here is it's an Aura, and Auras always need helping mechanics. This is directly replacing the card and can be used at instant speed, so it gets you card advantage when you time it right.

You enchant your creature.
Your opponent targets the creature.
Just by paying mana, you recoup the enchantment- now you're at 1:1 card advantage.
While you still need to spend a card to save your creature, you might be able to do so with a cantrip or token-making spell. Small Card Advantage.

-Or-

You enchant your creature.
Your opponent plays Disenchant and wants to block.
You cycle the enchantment from play, breaking even on cards.
Your creature kills the blocker. Card Advantage (probably would only come up in limited.)

While it's uses are certainly a bit narrow, it by no means has no use. 3 stars. you could argue for 2.5, but not less. :)

It's really difficult to actually create card advantage with it to be honest- BUT quite easy to make it come to breaking even! :) Enchant AURAMANCER if you want the simplest elegant strategy. (Presumably you are playing with more than 1 copy in your deck, and presumably you are playing other enchantments if you are playing this one at all)
Theming Enchanment-Auras together is not a bad way to build a deck at all- alone they could be weaker than you'd like, but the synergize very nicely very often. :) Rancor?

19115: Carnival of Souls.author: Gunhaven
19115: Carnival of Souls.text_parsed:
Right then, infinite combo with this card that I use with my EDH deck. It may be overly complicated and prone to destruction, but no one sees it coming.

Thopter Squadron (or similar token generator) +
(Carnival of Souls + Doubling Season / Copy Enchantment ) +
(Essence Warden / Soul Warden + )

So, let's take an example of the basic engine. Thopter Squadron is in play, as well as Carnival of Souls, Doubling Season, and an Essence Warden. You tap some land to remove a counter from Thopter - You create 2 tokens due to Doubling Season. Those tokens cause you to lose and then gain 2 life due to Essence and Carnival, as well as gain 2 Black Mana. Using the Black Mana you can sac a Thopter to put 2 +1/+1 counters back onto the Squadron. Finally, you use your last Black Mana to repeat the cycle.

Throw in a Boon Reflection/Second Warden/other life gainer dependent on Creatures and you get infinite life. Pandemonium lets you do infinite damage. And you have an infinitely large Thopter Squadron and an infinite number of Thopters to attack with.
19115: Carnival of Souls.text_posted:
Right then, infinite combo with this card that I use with my EDH deck.  It may be overly complicated and prone to destruction, but no one sees it coming.

[autocard]Thopter Squadron[/autocard] (or similar token generator) +
([autocard]Carnival of Souls[/autocard] + [autocard]Doubling Season[/autocard] / [autocard]Copy Enchantment[/autocard] [Choose 1]) +
([autocard]Essence Warden[/autocard] / [autocard]Soul Warden[/autocard] + [[autocard]Deathgreeter[/autocard] / [autocard]Moonlit Wake[/autocard] + [autocard]Boon Reflection[/autocard] [Choose 1])

So, let's take an example of the basic engine.  Thopter Squadron is in play, as well as Carnival of Souls, Doubling Season, and an Essence Warden.  You tap some land to remove a counter from Thopter - You create 2 tokens due to Doubling Season.  Those tokens cause you to lose and then gain 2 life due to Essence and Carnival, as well as gain 2 Black Mana.  Using the Black Mana you can sac a Thopter to put 2 +1/+1 counters back onto the Squadron.  Finally, you use your last Black Mana to repeat the cycle.

Throw in a Boon Reflection/Second Warden/other life gainer dependent on Creatures and you get infinite life.  Pandemonium lets you do infinite damage.  And you have an infinitely large Thopter Squadron and an infinite number of Thopters to attack with.

19115: Carnival of Souls.author: zk3
19115: Carnival of Souls.text_parsed:
Easier infinite mana combo:
Gather three copies of Faceless Butcher/Faceless Devourer and have (as mentioned before) Essence Warden or even Leyline of Lifeforce around. At the very least, you tie the game. At the best, you have some instant or another creature on the battlefield to Butcher, and then play Maga for the win.
These colors are pretty synergistic, as you can put together the combo pieces with Pack Hunt, Bifurcate, or Infernal Tutor. Dual Nature turns a single copy of Faceless into a combo. Bloodbond March acts as a sort of Yawgmoth's Will for the combo.

19115: Carnival of Souls.author: JaxsonBateman
19115: Carnival of Souls.text_parsed:
This is sub 3? Ke? It's a combo card, and not a bad one. Stick it into the combo deck, and just don't play it until you can offset the life loss, or your combo's going to go off.

Personally, I just put it into a BG Recurring Nightmare deck. Essence Warden offsets the life loss, so if I have a Kozilek's Predator in the grave and one on the board I can get infinite black mana, which means I can infinitely recur anything in my graveyard - say, Kokusho or Woodfall Primus for example. Given the deck runs Survival of the Fittest, the Kozileks aren't even difficult to get.

I'd give it a 4 just for infinite combo potential.
